text_01: If the patient does not understand your question the first time, try repeating it again; and in preference, consider rephrasing this so it is easier to understand. Rephrasing questions because the patient cannot answer in the way originally asked is a great way to encourage communication.
text_02: Avoid asking open-ended questions or giving too many answer choices. Instead, give simple choices (yes/no) and use pictures or objects to aid answers.
text_03: Remain on topic, focusing on one conversation subject at a time.
text_04: Give the patient time to respond. Don't fill silence with further or repeated questions.
text_05: Rephrase non-essential questions as suggestions. This allows the patient to comment and communicate as they wish to, with no pressure towards a predisposed answer. For example, instead of asking 'who is in this photo with you?', try suggesting 'that's a lovely photo'. Although using the environment to ask questions is a good technique to put the person at ease, it can actually be disheartening if they cannot answer your question due to memory or communication issues.
text_06: If you are struggling to communicate with the patient yourself, use others around you to help; as the patient may recognise their voice and be more open to conversation.
